Facile one-pot synthesis of niobium-containing carbon nitride and the catalytic application for synthesis of dimethyl carbonate Lin-Zhi Yu Writing – original draft Investigation Xue-Wen Zhang Investigation Formal analysis Fei Wang Validation Jie Xu Conceptualization Writing – review & editing ⁎ 1 Bing Xue Supervision ⁎ 2 Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Gehu Middle Road 21, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213164, PR China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University Gehu Middle Road 21 Changzhou Jiangsu 213164 PR China Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Gehu Middle Road 21, Changzhou, Jiangsu 213164, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 ORCID: 0000-0002-2413-8405 2 ORCID: 0000-0001-6740-4665 Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is a building block in wide chemical-related fields and the transesterification of ethylene carbonate (EC) and methanol/ethanol is a sustainable route for the synthesis of DMC. Herein, in order to explore efficient heterogeneous catalysts, niobium-containing carbon nitride materials were synthesized by a convenient one-pot calcination method. By reserving the main chemical functionalities of carbon nitride, the Nb-CN composites contained both acidic and basic properties, and Nb can be dispersed by carbon nitride. In the transesterification of EC with methanol, under the reaction temperature of 140 °C and reaction time of 4 h, the conversion of EC and the selectivity of DMC reached 53.8% and 100%, respectively, and the activity of the catalyst did not decrease significantly after several recycling runs. Furthermore, the Nb-CN could promote transesterification reactions of other cyclic carbonate and alcohols. Graphical Abstract Keywords Base catalyst Dimethyl carbonate Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) Niobium Transesterification Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As an important organic chemical intermediate, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has attracted tremendous attention in recent decades owing to its versatile reactivity [1,2]. DMC can serve as a non-toxic carbonylation or methylation reagent to substitute traditional poisonous phosgene and dimethyl sulfate in organic synthesis [3,4]. Moreover, DMC has been proposed as an environmentally benign additive to boost the octane number of gasoline because of its high content of oxygen and biodegradability [5,6]. In addition, DMC is widely used as an electrolyte in lithium-ion batteries [5]. There are several industrial routes through which DMC can be produced, including oxidative carbonylation of methanol, alcoholysis of urea [7,8], etc. Although these technologies are mature enough, the major drawback thereof is either the use of poisonous gases or the low yield of DMC [6,9]. The transesterification of cyclic carbonate represented by ethylene carbonate (EC) and methanol has been recently proposed as a sustainable strategy for the manufacture of DMC as the starting reactants (i.e. EC and methanol) are low-toxic substances [9,10] and meanwhile the transesterification reaction can be performed under milder conditions compared with the conventional process [11]. There are numerous catalysts reported to promote the transesterification reaction of EC and methanol. Among them, homogenous sodium methoxide (CH3ONa) is the widely implemented catalyst in industrial production; however, it is rather sensitive to water and CO2 [12,13]. Besides CH3ONa, ionic liquids have also shown excellent catalytic activity in the catalytic process, yet also suffer from product purification and catalyst recovery despite their high catalytic activity [3,14]. To circumvent this issue, ionic liquids are immobilized on solid supports, such as silica [15,16] and polymers [2,14,17]. By the transformation of homogeneous ionic liquids into heterogeneous solids, the original difficulty in product purification and catalyst recovery can be easily solved. Notwithstanding, the complicated preparation procedure and expensive coupling agents still hinder the further application of immobilized ionic liquids as practical catalysts for transesterification reactions. In this context, the exploration of sustainable heterogeneous catalysts has attracted increasing attention for the production of DMC via transesterification of EC. It should be noted that many heterogeneous catalysts including hydrotalcites, anion-exchange resins, and zeolites lack long-term stability and also require harsh reaction conditions [12]. In the last decade, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), as a new carbon-based material, has received extensive attention in photocatalysis [18,19] and thermal catalysis [20,21]. Owing to its abundance of nitrogen-containing groups in the graphitic layer, g-C3N4 is a typical solid base and is used to catalyze Knoevenagel condensation [22–24], transesterification [25–27] and CO2 conversion [20,28] reactions. In addition, some nitrogen species of g-C3N4 can disperse and anchor several metal ions (e.g. Zn [29], K [23,30], and Pd [31,32]) and thus be adopted as catalyst support. However, the g-C3N4 material synthesized by thermal condensation (i.e. direct calcination) has very low specific surface area and alkaline strength [33,34]. As for the transesterification reactions, g-C3N4 can activate alcohol molecules by its nitrogen-containing species, but can hardly activate ester molecules. On the other hand, Nb2O5 and other Nb-containing compounds [35,36] have been utilized as Lewis acids to promote the transesterification reaction. Unfortunately, the reported homogeneous Nb-containing catalysts suffered from shortcomings in catalyst separation while other heterogeneous catalysts had limited catalytic activity. Given this point, introducing acidic Nb species into the alkaline CN framework might provide efficient acid-base bifunctional materials for transesterification reactions. Herein, a series of Nb-containing carbon nitride materials (Nb-CN) were prepared by a one-pot calcination method using dicyandiamide and niobium oxalate as precursors. The characterization results showed that Nb could interact with N of CN via complexation under certain preparation conditions. The introduction of Nb not only introduced the acidic sites but also increased the alkaline strength of CN materials. In the transesterification reaction of ethylene carbonate (EC) and CH3OH, Nb-CN materials as acid-base bifunctional solids showed good catalytic activity. Under the reaction temperature of 140 °C and reaction time of 4 h, the conversion of EC and the selectivity of DMC reached 53.8% and 100%, respectively, and the activity of the catalyst did not decrease significantly after several recycling runs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Nb-CN Dicyandiamide (DCDA, 4 g) was added to 30 mL of anhydrous ethanol containing niobium oxalate (C10H5NbO20), and the suspension was stirred at 60 °C until the removal of ethanol. The obtained white solid is ground, transferred to a crucible (∼ 30 mL) with a cover in a muffle furnace, and heated to a desired temperature (T) with a heating slope of 2 °C min−1. The heating treatment was kept for 4 h. The resulting sample was labeled xNb-CN-T, where x and T represented the molar amount of Nb (mmol) and calcination temperature, respectively. Unless other specified, x and T were 0.25 and 550. For comparison, DCDA (4 g) was directly calcinated at 550 °C for 4 h. The resulting material was labeled as CN. Niobium oxalate (4 g) was directly calcinated at 550 °C for 3 h, and the obtained material was Nb2O5-550. 2.2 Material characterization The physicochemical properties of the materials were analyzed N2 adsorption–desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM), CO2/NH3 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-/NH3-TPD). Detailed information on the apparatuses and analytic methods are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation Transesterification of EC with CH3OH was performed in a stainless steel autoclave (10 mL). 250 mmol of CH3OH, 25 mmol of EC, and 0.1 g of the pre-dried catalyst were added into the autoclave and mixed well. After being filled with nitrogen gas up to ca. 0.6–0.8 MPa, the reactor was heated at 140 °C for 4 h under vigorous stirring. After the completion of the reaction (i.e. 4 h), the autoclave was cooled down in ice water and then exhausted slowly. The liquid-phase mixture was separated by centrifugation and analyzed by gas chromatography equipped with a SE-54 capillary column and FID. Owing to the higher stoichiometric of EC than CH3OH adopted in the reaction, the catalytic conversion was calculated based on EC. The detailed EC conversion and selectivity to the target molecule (DMC) were calculated based on an area-normalization method of GC. For the recycling experiment, the reaction mixture was filtrated, and the filtrated catalyst was rinsed with ethanol (95 wt%, a.q.) three times. After drying under 60 °C for 2 h, the recycled catalyst was used for the next catalytic run without the addition of the fresh catalyst. For clarity, the recycled catalyst subjected to five catalytic runs was named with a suffix of “-R” (e.g. 0.25 Nb-CN-550-R). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Materials characterization The N2 adsorption–desorption isothermal curve and pore size distribution (PSD) of CN, which was prepared by direct thermal condensation, are shown in Fig. S1. There is a hysteretic loop in the range of p/p 0 from 0.6 to 0.99, suggesting that the material contains mesostructured pores. The pore size thereof is ca. 3.5 nm, and the pores of CN are mainly from the interparticle voids. Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption desorption isothermal curves and pore size distributions of Nb-CN materials. The 0.25 Nb-CN materials also possessed mesostructured pores, and the sizes thereof are ca. 3 nm. The adsorption quantity of 0.25 Nb-CN-450 material is very low. As the preparation temperatures are elevated, the adsorption quantities are increased gradually. The corresponding specific surface area, pore sizes, and pore volumes of the materials are listed in Table 1. The CN material has a specific surface area of 17 m2·g−1 and a pore volume of 0.07 cm3·g−1. In the case of 0.25 Nb-CN-450, because the sample is prepared under low temperature, DCDA has not transformed into carbon nitride and there are no rich pores. As the calcination temperature is raised, carbon nitride is generated and meanwhile undergoes further self-decomposition, resulting in the apparent increase in terms of surface area and pore volumes. Fig. 2 describes the XRD patterns of Nb-CN materials with various preparation temperatures and loading amounts of Nb. The crystalline structure of Nb-CN-T materials is found to be related to the calcination temperatures. Except that of 0.25 Nb-CN-450, the patterns of other 0.25 Nb-CN-T materials exhibit two diffraction peaks at 2θ of 12.8 ° and 27.4 °, corresponding to the (100) and (002) reflections of graphitic structures [34,37]. Moreover, as the temperature is elevated, the intensity of the diffraction peaks becomes weaker. For the 0.25 Nb-CN-450, the multiple diffraction lines at 13.4, 25.1, and 27.2 ° are associated with melem, i.e. the intermediate during the thermal condensation of DCDA to carbon nitride [19]. The Nb-CN-550 materials with various loading amounts of Nb present similar diffraction peaks of graphitic structures. On the other hand, Nb2O5-550, which was prepared by direct calcination of niobium oxalate under 550 °C, shows pronounced diffraction peaks at 2θ of 22.6, 36.3, and 46.3 °, attributed to the (001), (101), and (002) planes of the pseudohexagonal structure of Nb2O5 (JCPDS: 28–0317) [38]. It should be noted that these peaks about Nb2O5 are not detected in the patterns of Nb-CN materials even with high loading amounts, which might be due to the limit of detection of XRD. The micro-morphology of the materials was characterized by SEM. Fig. 3 is the SEM images of CN and 0.25 Nb-CN-550. The image of CN reveals agglomerated large particles while 0.25 Nb-CN-550 possesses relatively small particles, coinciding with its larger surface area than that of CN (Table 1). The corresponding EDX mapping is shown in Fig. 4, and it is found that carbon, nitrogen, and niobium elements are well distributed on the 0.25 Nb-CN-550 material. Fig. 5 describes the FT-IR spectra of CN and 0.25 Nb-CN materials, and all the spectra show three similar vibrational regions. The sharp transmission peaks at 811 cm−1 correspond to the breathing mode of the heptazine structure. The multiple weak but pronounced bands between 1643 and 1239 cm−1 are associated with stretching modes of aromatic nitrogen-containing heterocyclic rings, while the broad peaks at 3404–2976 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of adsorbed water and amino groups [25,37]. These three transmittance regions are indicative of conjugated graphitic carbon nitride with heptazine rings as motif units. As illustrated in Fig. 5, The 0.25 Nb-CN materials resemble CN in the FT-IR spectra, suggesting that the loading of Nb has not altered the chemical functionalities of the original carbon nitride, and nitrogen-containing groups are well reserved in 0.25 Nb-CN materials. The UV–vis spectra of the above materials are shown in Fig. 6. The spectra of all the materials reveal obvious absorption in the ultraviolet region, which is caused by the electronic transition between the HOMO and LUMO of the conjugated heptazine groups of the CN material [39]. Except for that of 0.25 Nb-CN-450, the absorption intensity in the UV region of 0.25 Nb-CN is much higher than CN, and meanwhile, the absorption edge moves towards the longer wavelength. Such a red shift was also observed in the published papers involving metal-doped CN materials [40–42], which implies an interaction between the metal cation and nitrogen species of CN as the preparation temperature of 0.25 Nb-CN reaches 550 °C. The surface chemical environment of these materials was further analyzed by XPS. Fig. 7 shows the XPS survey spectra of CN, niobium oxalate, and 0.25 Nb-CN materials prepared with various calcination temperatures. The two intensive signals with binding energies of 285 and 399 eV detected in CN are indexed as C and N elements. Besides the two peaks, the spectrum of niobium oxalate shows other peaks at 208 and 533 eV, corresponding to Nb and O elements [38]. As for 0.25 Nb-CN, the signals of Nb are very weak. Notwithstanding, as the preparation temperatures of 0.25 Nb-CN are above 550 °C, the Nb peak can be observed in Fig. 7. The detailed chemical compositions of the materials were calculated by the XPS survey and summarized in Table 2. In comparison with CN, 0.25 Nb-CN materials possess higher molar C/N ratios. In this study, the 0.25 Nb-CN materials were prepared by thermal treatment. During the thermal transformation of niobium oxalate to Nb2O5, the CN support also suffered thermal decomposition. Wherein, partial nitrogen-containing species in CN support would decompose, resulting in higher carbon content in 0.25 Nb-CN materials. This could also explain the gradual increase in Nb content from 0.25 Nb-CN-450–0.25 Nb-CN-600. Fig. 8 In order to further investigate the distribution of nitrogen species in the materials, the fine spectra of N 1 s of CN and 0.25 Nb-CN materials were recorded and then deconvoluted. In the case of CN, the spectrum can be divided into three peaks. The primary peak with a binding energy of 398.2 eV corresponds to the sp2-hybridized N atoms (Na) in the heptazine unit structure [43,44]. The peaks at 399.1 and 400.5 eV are indexed as the N atoms connecting heptazine units (also called bridging N atoms, Nb) and terminal amino groups (Nc) at the edge of the heptazine rings, respectively [21]. Likewise, the spectra of 0.25 Nb-CN were also separated into three peaks. The detailed distributions of nitrogen species are listed in Table 2. The 0.25 Nb-CN-450 has a very similar distribution of nitrogen species with CN; however, adopting high temperatures results in variation. Among the three samples, 0.25 Nb-CN-550 has the highest percentage of Nb species. Obviously, the thermal treatment could facilitate the transformation of Nc to Nb species. Fig. 9 shows the fine spectra of Nd 3d of niobium oxalate and 0.25 Nb-CN materials. Two independent peaks attributed to 3d 3/2 (210.3 eV) and 3d 5/2 (207.6 eV) can be resolved in the spectrum of niobium oxalate [45,46]. The spectra of 0.25 Nb-CN have lower intensities than those of niobium oxalate, mainly because of the low content of Nb in 0.25 Nb-CN composites. More importantly, the positions of the two peaks acquired in 0.25 Nb-CN reveal a remarkable shift towards lower binding energies in comparison with niobium oxalate, indicating Nb in 0.25 Nb-CN has a richer negative charge environment. This should be due to the solid interaction between Nb and N, like other metal-doped carbon nitride materials [47,48]. 3.2 Catalyst activity The catalytic activity of the materials was evaluated in the transesterification of EC and CH3OH with reaction temperature and time of 140 °C and 4 h, respectively. As shown in Table 3, In the absence of any catalysts, the EC conversion is 26% and the selectivity to the target molecule (i.e. DMC) is 100%. Upon adding 100 mg of CN, the conversion is increased slightly. As mentioned above, CN is a typical solid base, which could promote the transesterification reaction. However, the catalytic activity is indeed limited. Also, the catalytic activity of Nb2O5-550 was tested and the EC conversion thereof is 33.8%, indicating that the use of sole CN base or Nb2O5 acid is hardly to promote the transesterification reaction in this study. By comparison, the use of Nb-CN composites as catalysts shows further improvement in the productivity of DMC. As the loading amount of Nb is increased, the conversion of EC is enhanced first but decreased later, and the highest conversion (53.8%) is achieved in the case of 0.25 Nb-CN. Table 4 lists the catalytic performances of 0.25 Nb-CN materials prepared with various temperatures. It is found that the catalytic activity is also sensitive to the preparation temperature. For 0.25 Nb-CN-450 with low preparation temperature, the EC conversion is only 35.9%. As the temperature is elevated, the conversion is improved. However, as the preparation temperature is as high as 600 °C, the conversion decreases significantly. The variation in catalytic activity might be partially due to their surface areas and pore volumes (Table 1). That is, a higher surface area means that the catalyst can expose more active sites in the reaction thus improving the final catalytic activity. Nevertheless, the 0.25 Nb-CN-600 has the highest surface area yet lowest activity, implying besides textural parameters, there are other factors determining the catalytic activity of 0.25 Nb-CN materials. As described above, many Nb-containing compounds are classical solid acids, which have been proven to be able to catalyze acid-mediated esterification and transesterification reactions. Fig. 10 describes the NH3-TPD profiles of CN and 0.25 Nb-CN materials. The CN material shows broad desorption signals from 150 to 400 °C, which is ascribed to its physical adsorption of NH3 and slight decomposition of nitrogen-containing species in CN. In the cases of 0.25 Nb-CN materials, distinct desorption peaks can be observed in the range of ca. 200–300 °C, corresponding to the weak acidic sites on the surface of 0.25 Nb-CN materials. Specifically, among the three samples, despite its moderate surface area, the 0.25 Nb-CN-550 sample exhibits the highest decomposition temperature as well as intensity. As revealed in XPS, the Nb-CN materials contain nitrogen-containing species and we also analyzed the alkaline properties of these materials by CO2-TPD ( Fig. 11). Unlike the profile in NH3-TPD, a desorption peak emerges in the range of 175–325 °C in CO2-TPD profile of CN, confirming that the material possesses weak alkaline sites. In comparison, the Nb-CN materials demonstrate notable and intensive desorption peaks between 150 and 275 °C. Furthermore, the position of the desorption peak obtained in the case of 0.25 Nb-CN-550 is at much higher temperatures than its counterparts. This means that the material has superior strength of alkaline sites. Undoubtedly, the alkaline property of 0.25 Nb-CN is attributed to the nitrogen-containing species of CN component, which thus endow 0.25 Nb-CN materials with acid-base duality. Fig. 12 shows the catalytic performance of 0.25 Nb-CN-550 at various reaction temperatures by using 0.25 Nb-CN-550 as a representative catalyst. As the reaction temperature is 110 °C, the conversion is only 14.4%, and the conversion increases progressively from 110 to 140 °C. As the temperatures are higher than 140 °C, there are no significant increments in conversion. The influences of reaction time and catalyst dosage on catalytic performance were further explored. As shown in Fig. 13 A, the EC conversion is only 11.3% at the reaction time of 1 h; as the reaction proceeds, the conversion increases gradually. After the reaction of 4 h, the conversion increases slowly and reaches up to 64.7% at 6 h. Fig. 13 B shows the catalytic performance of transesterification with various catalyst dosages. The conversion is only 24.5% in the case of 25 mg of catalyst. As the dosage of catalyst is over 100 mg, the conversion shows a slight increase when adopting more catalyst. Specifically, as the catalyst mass increases from 100 mg to 200 mg, the conversion increases only from 53.8% to 60.8%. In view of the effects of the above reaction conditions on the catalytic performance, the reaction time of 4 h and catalyst dosage of 100 mg are adopted as optimal reaction conditions. In addition to the catalytic activity and selectivity, recyclability and reproductivity are also important aspects to evaluate the performance of a heterogeneous catalyst. Herein, we carried out a series of recycling experiments using 0.25 Nb-CN-550 as a model catalyst. As shown in Fig. 14, the EC conversions within the five consecutive tests decreased from 61% to 50% whereas the DMC selectivities are all 100%. This slight decrease in terms of catalytic activity may be due to the loss of part of the catalyst during the catalyst recovery procedure. In general, the catalyst shows stable recycling performance in the transesterification reactions. The recycled catalyst is analyzed by N2 adsorption–desorption (Fig. 1), XRD (Fig. S2), FT-IR (Fig. 5), and XPS (Table 2 and Fig. 9), and the corresponding results show that the main chemical compositions of the recovered catalyst have no significant difference compared with the fresh one, further confirming that the catalyst has good recycling ability in the transesterification reaction. Besides EC and CH3OH, we have also used PC (propylene carbonate) and C2H5OH as substrates to examine the catalytic activity of 0.25 Nb-CN-550. As listed in Table 5, the conversion of PC is lower than in the case of EC. This is because the carbonyl carbon atom in PC is less reactive than that of EC [49]. Notwithstanding, adopting a higher reaction temperature can bring out an improvement in PC conversion. On the other hand, although the O–H bond in C2H5OH is more difficult to dissociate than CH3OH, the conversion of EC is also up to 23.9% in the case of transesterification of EC and C2H5OH. In addition, the transesterification of EC with cyclohexanol and phenol using 0.25 Nb-CN-550 as a catalyst was also conducted. Under the same reaction conditions, the conversions of cyclohexanol and phenol were unfortunately lower than 5%. Even under higher reaction temperature up to 160 °C, the final conversions of EC were still lower than 10%. By contrast, the EC conversions achieved under 140 °C was 53.8%. The difference in catalytic activity adopting cyclohexanol, phenol, and methanol should be due to the reactivity of the alcohols themselves. Compared with methanol, cyclohexanol and phenol have greater steric hindrance. In fact, to the best of our knowledge, for the transesterification reaction of EC, most of the alcohols reported are low alcohols, especially methanol, and ethanol, whereas the use of cyclohexanol and phenol as alcohol substrates for the transesterification of EC is rarely reported [50–52]. Nevertheless, the above tests prove that the catalyst has relative applicability for the catalytic synthesis of cyclic carbonates via transesterification of low alcohol substrates. Table 6 summarizes the catalytic performance of several metal-oxide and g-C3N4-based catalysts for the transesterification of EC and CH3OH reported in the last three years. The reaction temperatures are mostly above 90 °C, and the molar ratios of EC to CH3OH are 1:10 and 1:8. Among these catalysts, CaO/carbon, Co-Ca-Zr, and CuO/ZnO-9%K2O materials exhibit the highest catalytic activity even under lower reaction temperatures (60–90 °C). All these catalysts contain alkali or alkaline-earth metals, and despite their high activity, the active alkaline components are very easy to adsorb acidic CO2, resulting in subsequent slow inactivation [53]. In the cases of g-C3N4-based catalysts, the reaction conditions are very similar. In the viewpoint of the apparent catalytic conversion of EC, the catalytic performance of Nb-CN in this study is indeed lower than its counterparts. However, it should be stressed that other g-C3N4-based catalysts were basically prepared via two or more steps, including exfoliation, and impregnation or post treatment. In this regard, combining its convenient preparation and stable catalytic recyclability, Nb-CN could serve as a more practical heterogeneous catalyst for transesterification reactions. 4 Conclusion In summary, Nb-CN materials were synthesized by a one-pot calcination method using niobium oxalate and DCDA as precursors. The introduction of Nb does not change the graphitic structure of CN material, and there exists a probable interaction between Nb and nitrogen of CN. According to the characterization results of XPS, NH3-TPD, and CO2-TPD, Nb-CN materials have both acidic and alkaline sites. As heterogeneous catalysts, the Nb-CN composites demonstrate good catalytic activity in the transesterification reaction of EC. Among the various Nb-CN materials, Nb-CN-550 shows the highest acidic and alkaline strength. As the reaction temperature and time are 140 °C and 4 h, a maximum yield of DMC is obtained in the case of 0.25 Nb-CN-550. It is anticipated that the highest catalytic activity of Nb-CN-550 is derived from its combination of superior strength of acid and base. Combining its good catalytic activity and recyclability, the acid-base bifunctional catalyst can provide a new strategy for the clean and efficient synthesis of DMC. coredata.dc:description: Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is a building block in wide chemical-related fields and the transesterification of ethylene carbonate (EC) and methanol/ethanol is a sustainable route for the synthesis of DMC. Herein, in order to explore efficient heterogeneous catalysts, niobium-containing carbon nitride materials were synthesized by a convenient one-pot calcination method. By reserving the main chemical functionalities of carbon nitride, the Nb-CN composites contained both acidic and basic properties, and Nb can be dispersed by carbon nitride. In the transesterification of EC with methanol, under the reaction temperature of 140 °C and reaction time of 4 h, the conversion of EC and the selectivity of DMC reached 53.8% and 100%, respectively, and the activity of the catalyst did not decrease significantly after several recycling runs. Furthermore, the Nb-CN could promote transesterification reactions of other cyclic carbonate and alcohols.
coredata.dc:title: Facile one-pot synthesis of niobium-containing carbon nitride and the catalytic application for synthesis of dimethyl carbonate
